contentrichtext.text: {{refimprove|date=October 2010}} '''Manu Herbstein''' (born 1936) is the [[South Africa]]n author of ''[[Ama: A Story of the Atlantic Slave Trade]]'' (2001), which won the 2002 [[Commonwealth Writers Prize]] for Best First Book, the first time the award had been given to an electronic book.<ref> {{cite news |title=Richard Flanagan wins Commonwealth prize |first=Emma |last=Yates |newspaper=The Guardian |date=2002-04-25 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/books/2002/apr/25/news.awardsandprizes }}</ref> The companion web site to his novel is at http://www.ama.africatoday.com where the first chapter may be read on-line. == References == {{reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}} {{Authority control|VIAF=29466730}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Herbstein, Manu | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 1936 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Herbstein, Manu}} [[Category:South African Jews]] [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:South African writers]] [[Category:Living people]] {{SouthAfrica-writer-stub}}
